title: 108_hr1394
content: The Act titled "Intermodal Transportation Act of 2003" establishes the Intermodal Transportation Facilities Program. The Intermodal Transportation Facilities Program, established by the Intermodal Transportation Act of 2003, involves the Secretary making grants for intermodal transportation projects to promote passenger transportation. Grants are awarded on a competitive basis to public or private entities for construction, maintenance, and renovation of facilities. Eligible recipients receive grants directly for developing or operating the facilities. The Intermodal Transportation Facilities Program, established in 2003, offers grants for intermodal transportation projects connecting various transit services. Eligible projects include facilities linking urban or rural transit services with intercity bus and rail services, as well as connecting different transportation modes with commercial air services. Additionally, the program supports facilities providing park and ride services. The Intermodal Transportation Facilities Program, established in 2003, offers grants for projects connecting various transit services, including park and ride facilities, intercity bus and rail connections, and other intermodal facilities. Priority is given to projects integrating all available modes of transportation, with a federal share of up to 90 percent of project costs. Grants are contingent on projects being part of an approved program and meeting planning requirements. Section 5333(b) applies to projects receiving assistance under the Intermodal Transportation Facilities Program, with a contractual obligation of the United States Government to pay the project costs. Authorization of $100,000,000 from the Highway Trust Fund is available annually for fiscal years 2004 through 2009. The Intermodal facilities program is authorized with $100,000,000 annually from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2004 through 2009. Rural connections to airports are addressed in Section 3. The Secretary of Transportation will implement a program to support intercity bus and commercial van services between non-urbanized areas and primary airports. States must use allocated funds for eligible transportation projects in their annual program submitted to the Secretary for approval. The Secretary will apportion funds among states for eligible intercity bus and commercial van service projects, including planning, capital grants for facilities, operating grants, and security enhancements for passengers connecting to air services. The Federal government will fund up to 90% of intercity bus and commercial van service projects, with states able to contract with private operators to provide essential services without duplicating existing services. The Federal government will finance up to 90% of intercity bus and commercial van service projects. Amounts apportioned to a State under this section will remain available until expended. Authorization of appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund includes $30,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2004, 2005, and 2006, and $35,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2007, 2008, and 2009. The funding for rural transportation accessibility incentive program is increased to $15,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2009. Additionally, $5,000,000 will be available for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2009 for the National Transportation Information System. The Secretary will establish a national public transportation information system, prioritizing coordination with States and private entities. The system will include information on service, fares, schedules, and accessibility for persons with disabilities. The national public transportation information system will include providers of various transportation services and be accessible to the public in real-time. It must be fully operational within 5 years and can be implemented through private contractors. The Federal government will share the cost of projects related to this system. Authorization of Appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund for the national public transportation information system: $20,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2004 and 2005, and $10,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2006 through 2009. Such sums shall remain available until expended. SEC. 6. Capital projects are defined as excluding commercial revenue-producing facilities not intended for mass transportation or intercity bus/rail transportation. Capital investment grants and loans cover costs of coordinating mass transportation with other modes, enhancing coordination.
